description:
Around the world, we're all on average living longer. Great news you may say. But as the old adage goes, "Ageing is the only option to living a long life." And a population of old people is expansive. They require more care. So who pays for that? It's an issue few countries are addressing head-on. Many are too busy cutting back on spending. In a moment, we'll hear why even developing countries with big young populations are worried. But first the World Health Organization says that soon the world will have more older people than children, and more people of very old age than ever before. By the year 2050, nearly 2 billion people on the planet will be aged 60 or more. Some 400 million will be 80 or over. And when it comes to ageing populations, Japan, as the Economist magazine puts it, is the wizened canary in the world's coal mine. It's become older faster than any other big industrialised country. The BBC's Mariko Oi reports.

Shall we go home? Asks 29-year-old Midori Ide. She's come to pick up her grandmother from a nursing home. Her grandma replies with a big smile. At the age of 96, every step from the car to the house requires assistance.
